Gregory Jonason

(2) Abstract

Multimedia is a broad term for pictures, audio and video. Pictures include both images and graphics. Until HTML5, images were the only multimedia content on the Web widely supported by standardized formats. With the arrival of HTML5, audio and video are now supported directly by Web browsers, and there is wider support for graphics as well.



Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(3) Images vs. Graphics

  • Pictures can be encoded in a wide variety of ways [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_graphics_file_formats]
  • Images are bitmaps of pixels
    • it takes scanning/rendering to produce images
    • images have a certain native resolution
    • scanning is done by a scanner, a fax, or a camera's CCD [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge-coupled_device]
  • Vector Graphics are composed out of graphic primitives
    • graphics can be searchable, stylable, and scalable
    • the format can have different capabilities (2D vs. 3D)
  • Graphics preserve model-level information
    • this only makes sense if there is a model
    • rendering and styling can be an expensive process (e.g., video games)
    • images can be a snapshot of some specific view of graphics

Images on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(5) JPEG, GIF and PNG

  • To recap [Media Types (MIME); Image Content Types (1)]:
  • JPEG is the format of choice for photographic images
  • GIF was the original format of choice for drawn images such as logos or diagrams
  • PNG is the new format of choice, though there are still more GIF images on the Web
    • PNG supports alpha transparency [http://www-archive.mozilla.org/start/1.0/demos/eagle-sun.html]
    • GIF supports animation [http://people.ischool.berkeley.edu/~ryanshaw/gucci/], which accounts for its enduring popularity
    • recent versions of Firefox have support for animated PNGs, which are superior [http://animatedpng.com/index.php/samples/samples-by-codadude/]


Images on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(6) JPEG 2000

  • There are no new Web image formats on the forseeable horizon
  • One contender was the next generation of JPEG: JPEG 2000 [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JPEG_2000]
  • JPEG 2000 allows for progressive transmission
    • when viewing very high-resolution images, more detail can be downloaded and added to the image as the user zooms in
    • something similar is offered by Microsoft's (proprietary) Seadragon [http://www.seadragon.com/showcase/chris-jordan/#skull-with-cigarette] technology
  • But support for JPEG 2000 on the Web seems to have stalled


Graphics on the Web

Graphics on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(8) Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG)

  • JPEG, GIF and PNG are raster [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raster_graphics] formats
    • they represent pictures using a grid of pixels
  • SVG is a vector [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bitmap_VS_SVG.svg] format
    • it represents pictures as combinations of lines and shapes
    • the lines and shapes are defined using XML
    • cannot be used for photographic images
  • SVG has been a W3C recommendation since 2003 but only recently started getting widespread browser support


Graphics on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(9) SVG Demos

  • Web-based SVG editor [http://svg-edit.googlecode.com/svn/branches/2.4/editor/svg-editor.html]
  • PNG tiger [http://www.w3.org/1999/09/SVG-access/tiger.png] vs. SVG tiger [http://codinginparadise.org/projects/svgweb/samples/demo.html?name=tiger&svg.render.forceflash=false]
  • Population graphs [http://vis.uell.net/gsvg/poppyr.html]
  • Voting maps [http://vis.uell.net/gsvg/electionAtlasGermany.html]
  • Animated lyrics [http://svg-wow.org/audio/animated-lyrics.svg] (Safari & Chrome only)
  • Light table [http://svg-wow.org/photoAlbum/light-table.svg]
  • Embedded browser [http://people.mozilla.com/~prouget/demos/svg/foreignobject.svg] (Firefox only)


Graphics on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(10) Canvas

  • Canvas not a format, it is a new HTML element
  • It creates an area in an HTML page which can be drawn on using Javascript commands
  • Demos:
    • Drawing pad [http://htmlfive.appspot.com/static/draw.html]
    • First-person gifter [http://htmlfive.appspot.com/static/gifter.html]


Graphics on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(11) SVG vs. Canvas

  • SVG and Canvas are complementary technologies
  • SVG:
    • import and export from tools like Inkscape [http://inkscape.org/] and Illustrator [http://www.adobe.com/products/illustrator/]
    • easier to create interfaces that can be interacted with via the mouse (such as charts and graphs)
    • basic animation is easy, advanced animation is hard
  • Canvas
    • can do sophisticated animation (such as video games)
    • no mouse interaction, just keyboard
  • It often makes sense to combine the two
    • Firefox stats [http://www.mozilla.com/en-US/firefox/stats/]


Video and Audio on the Web

Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(13) Codecs and Containers

  • A codec is an algorithm used to compress a digital audio or video signal
  • A container format is a particular file format used to deliver compressed audio or video
    • An audio container usually just contains one compressed audio track, plus metadata
    • A video container may contain multiple video and audio tracks, captions or subtitles, plus metadata
  • Note that we do not make a distinction between codec and container for digital images [Images on the Web (1)]
    • for example a PNG file can only hold PNG-compressed image data


Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(14) Codecs and Containers



Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(15) Download vs. Streaming

  • Web resources usually are downloaded
    • browsers may choose to implement incremental rendering (e.g., HTML or images)
    • the resource is completely downloaded and stored
  • Streaming [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streaming_media] means that there is no complete download
    • TV and phone calls are classical examples of streaming
    • some data sources cannot be downloaded (e.g., a live web cam)
  • Streaming often is also used because of security issues
    • downloads make it easy to get content and redistribute it
    • streaming makes redistribution much harder (content must be destreamed [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destreaming])
    • the data formats for streaming are often undisclosed


Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(16) Audio on the Web

  • Internet radios such as Pandora [http://www.pandora.com/] often use Flash
    • they are standalone applications running in a browser
    • content is often delivered via HTTP to circumvent firewalls
  • Audio formats exist in many different variations
    • MPEG1 Layer 3 (MP3) [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MP3] was the first widely supported audio format
    • audio streaming formats often use much less bandwidth


Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(17) Video on the Web

  • Unlike audio, where MP3 quickly became standard, video codecs and containers proliferated without a clear standard
  • Until a few years ago (2005-2006) it was still common for sites to offer video in multiple formats, or to exclude certain operating systems
  • In 2002, Macromedia added video support to Flash
    • The widespread availability of the Flash plugin (99% of browsers) made it a good choice for distributing video on the Web
    • In 2005, the phenomenal success of YouTube made Flash video the de facto standard


Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(18) Audio & Video in HTML5

  • HTML5 added audio and video elements
  • Browsers that support these (Firefox, Safari, Chrome, Opera) can play video and audio without Flash
  • The browser must also support the container and codec used
    • Firefox only supports the free Ogg [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ogg] container and its free codecs
    • Safari only supports what can be played through Quicktime (i.e. not Ogg)
    • HTML5 authors can specify multiple source files for an audio or video element to handle this situation
  • Now there is finally a credible alternative to Flash for audio and video on the Web


Video and Audio on the Web Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(19) HTML5 Video Demos

  • Basic video playback [http://htmlfive.appspot.com/static/video.html]
  • Filtering, clipping and transforming video with CSS and SVG
    • demo 1 [http://people.mozilla.com/~prouget/demos/mashup/video.xhtml]
    • demo 2 [http://people.mozilla.com/~prouget/demos/round/index.xhtml]
  • Injecting content into video [http://people.mozilla.com/~prouget/demos/DynamicContentInjection/play.xhtml]


Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Multimedia

(20) Conclusions

  • Image formats serve different purposes on the Web
    • PNG for graphics and JPEG for photographic images
    • GIF should be avoided (still required for animated images)
  • Until recently, audio and video had to be handled via a plugin (usually Flash)
  • With HTML5, there is finally native support for audio and video in the Web
